section-block.flip_chart-concept-question: How can we help plants grow?

flip_chart-teacher-facing-content-box.flip_chart-teacher-facing-paragraph: Once upon a time there was a boy named Jack who lived with his mother. They lived in a little house.
“Jack,” said his mother. “Please take our old cow to the market and sell it. Then we will have gold coins to buy things.”
On his way to the market, Jack met an old man. “I will trade you a handful of beans for your cow,” said the old man.
“Our cow is worth much more than a handful of beans,” said Jack.
“But these are magic beans,” said the old man.
Jack was very curious about the magic beans. So Jack traded their cow for the beans.
When he told his mother about the magic beans, she said, “That was a very foolish thing to do.” Then she tossed the beans out the window.
Jack went out and watered the magic beans. He wanted them to grow.
That night, while Jack was asleep, one little bean started to grow.
The next morning, the little bean plant got plenty of sunlight. Jack kept two hungry rabbits away from the bean plant. He watered the bean plant again.
The little plant grew and grew and grew. It grew all the way up to the clouds. Jack looked up at the giant beanstalk.
Jack was very curious about the giant beanstalk. So he grabbed hold of it and began to climb it. Jack climbed and climbed. Soon he was above the clouds.
The first thing he saw was a huge house. He looked in and saw a huge table and huge chairs.
BOOM! BOOM! BOOM!
A giant and his wife stormed in.
“Fee Fie Fo Fum! I think there is someone in our house,” said the giant.
“Nonsense, dear husband!” said his wife.
“There is no one here but you, and me, and our wonderful goose. Be kind to our goose that lays the golden eggs for us,” she said.
But the giant didn’t listen. He yelled at the goose.
“Goose!” commanded the mean giant. “Lay a golden egg now!”
And the sad goose laid an egg made of pure gold.
Jack felt sorry for the sad goose. He wanted to save the goose from the mean giant. So while the giants were busy eating dinner, Jack saved the goose.
Jack grabbed the goose and ran to the beanstalk. Then he began to climb down.
Just then, the giants saw the beanstalk move. They rushed to the beanstalk. They looked down from above the clouds and saw Jack.
Jack reached the ground quickly. Then he chopped down the beanstalk as fast as he could. Now the giant could not be mean to the goose anymore.
From that day on, the goose laid eggs of gold for Jack and his mother. And they lived happily ever after.
